standard_metadata.standard_description: Find whole-number quotients and remainders with up to four-digit dividends and one-digit divisors, using strategies based on place value, the properties of operations, and/or the relationship between multiplication and division. Illustrate and explain the calculation by using equations, rectangular arrays, and/or area models.

hints.content: $\begin{align}  {391}&\\ {\underline{{}\times\phantom{~}7}} & \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 39\blueE{1}&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonD{7}}&\\ \greenE{7}&\quad \maroonD{7} \times \blueE{1\text{ one}} \\ \end{align}$
$\begin{align} 3\blueE{9}1&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonD{7}}&\\ 7&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ \greenE{630}&\quad \maroonD{7} \times \blueE{9\text{ tens}} \\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{3}91&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonD{7}}&\\ 7&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ {630}&\quad {7} \times {9\text{ tens}} \\ \underline{{}+\greenE{2{,}100}}&\quad \maroonD{7} \times \blueE{3\text{ hundreds}} \\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 391&\\ \underline{{} \times 7}&\\ \purpleD{7}&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ \purpleD{630}&\quad {7} \times {9\text{ tens}}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{2{,}100}}&\quad {7} \times {3\text{ hundreds}}\\ 2{,}737 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 391&\\ \underline{{} \times 7}&\\ {7}&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ {630}&\quad {7} \times {9\text{ tens}}\\ \underline{{}+{2{,}100}}&\quad {7} \times {3\text{ hundreds}}\\ 2{,}737 \end{align}$

$\begin{align} \blueE{3}91&\\ \underline{{} \times \maroonD{7}}&\\ 7&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ {630}&\quad {7} \times {9\text{ tens}} \\ \underline{{}+\greenE{2{,}100}}&\quad \maroonD{7} \times \blueE{3\text{ hundreds}} \\ \end{align}$

$\begin{align} 391&\\ \underline{{} \times 7}&\\ \purpleD{7}&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ \purpleD{630}&\quad {7} \times {9\text{ tens}}\\ \underline{{}+\purpleD{2{,}100}}&\quad {7} \times {3\text{ hundreds}}\\ 2{,}737 \end{align}$

Here is the completed equation using partial products:  $\begin{align} 391&\\ \underline{{} \times 7}&\\ {7}&\quad {7} \times 1{\text{ one}} \\ {630}&\quad {7} \times {9\text{ tens}}\\ \underline{{}+{2{,}100}}&\quad {7} \times {3\text{ hundreds}}\\ 2{,}737 \end{align}$

question.content: Erin tried to evaluate $417\div3$ using partial quotients.  Her work is shown below.  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {3}&\overline{|417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\purpleD{300}}&\purpleD{100}&{}\times 3& \purpleD{\text{ Step 1}}\\ &117\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueD{90}}&\blueD{30}&{}\times 3&\blueD{\text{ Step 2}}\\ &27\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\redD{27}}&\underline{{}+\redD{9}}&{}\times 3&\redD{\text{ Step 3}}\\ &{0}&\greenE{139}&&\greenD{\text{ Step 4}} \end{array}$  **Find Erin's mistake.**

options.content: Erin did not make a mistake.

hints.content: Let's complete each step to see if we can find Erin's mistake.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 4\blueD{8}&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueD{2}}&\\ \blueD{16}&\quad \blueD{2} \times \blueD{8\text{ ones}} \end{align}$   $\blueD2\times\blueD8=\blueD{16}$, so Erin did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} \greenD{4}8&\\ \underline{{} \times \greenD{2}}&\\ 16&\quad {2} \times {8\text{ ones}} \\ \underline{{}+\greenD{80}}&\quad \greenD{2} \times \greenD{4\text{ tens}} \end{align}$  $\greenD2\times\greenD{40}=\greenD{80}$, so Erin did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 48&\\ \underline{{} \times 2}&\\ {16}&\qquad{2\times 8 \text{ ones}}\\ \underline{{}+{80}}&\qquad {2} \times 4 \text{ tens}\\ \maroonD{96} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{16}+\maroonD{80}=\maroonD{96}$, so Erin did not make a mistake in step $3$.
Erin did not make a mistake.

question.content: Erin tried to evaluate $417\div3$ using partial quotients.  Her work is shown below.  **OPTION #1**  $\begin{array}{rr|r|l} &{\goldD3}\overline{)417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{{\purpleD{300}}}&\purpleD{300}{}\div \goldD3 = \greenD{100}& \purpleD{\text{ Step 1}}\\ &117\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueD{90}}&{\blueD{90}}{}\div \goldD3=~~\greenD{30}&\blueD{\text{ Step 2}}\\ &27\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\redD{27}}&\redD{27}\div\goldD3 = \underline{{}\greenD{+9}}&{}\redD{\text{ Step 3}}\\ &{0}&\greenD{139}&\greenD{\text{ Step 4}} \end{array}$  **OPTION #2**  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} &{\goldD3}\overline{)417}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{{\purpleD{300}}}&\purpleD{300}{}\div \goldD3 = \greenD{100}& \purpleD{\text{ Step 1}}\\ &117\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueD{90}}&{\blueD{90}}{}\div \goldD3=~~\greenD{30}&\blueD{\text{ Step 2}}\\ &27\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{\redD{27}}&\redD{27}\div\goldD3 = \underline{{}\greenD{+9}}&{}\redD{\text{ Step 3}}\\ &{0}&\greenD{139}&\greenD{\text{ Step 4}} \end{array}$  **OPTION #3**  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} &{\goldD3}\overline{)417}\\ \purpleD{\text{ Step 1}}&\mathllap{-}\underline{{\purpleD{300}}}&\purpleD{300}{}\div \goldD3 = \greenD{100}& \\ &117\\ \blueD{\text{ Step 2}}&\mathllap{-}\underline{\blueD{90}}&{\blueD{90}}{}\div \goldD3=~~\greenD{30}&\\ &27\\ {}\redD{\text{ Step 3}}&\mathllap{-}\underline{\redD{27}}&\redD{27}\div\goldD3 = \underline{{}\greenD{+9}}&\\ \greenD{\text{ Step 4}}&{0}&\greenD{139}& \end{array}$  **Find Erin's mistake.**

options.content: Erin did not make a mistake.

hints.content: Let's complete each step to see if we can find Erin's mistake.

###Step $1$  $\begin{align} 4\blueD{8}&\\ \underline{{} \times \blueD{2}}&\\ \blueD{16}&\quad \blueD{2} \times \blueD{8\text{ ones}} \end{align}$   $\blueD2\times\blueD8=\blueD{16}$, so Erin did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$  $\begin{align} \greenD{4}8&\\ \underline{{} \times \greenD{2}}&\\ 16&\quad {2} \times {8\text{ ones}} \\ \underline{{}+\greenD{80}}&\quad \greenD{2} \times \greenD{4\text{ tens}} \end{align}$  $\greenD2\times\greenD{40}=\greenD{80}$, so Erin did not make a mistake in step $2$.

###Step $3$  $\begin{align} 48&\\ \underline{{} \times 2}&\\ {16}&\qquad{2\times 8 \text{ ones}}\\ \underline{{}+{80}}&\qquad {2} \times 4 \text{ tens}\\ \maroonD{96} \end{align}$  $\maroonD{16}+\maroonD{80}=\maroonD{96}$, so Erin did not make a mistake in step $3$.
Erin did not make a mistake.

question.content: Aria and Brynn try to divide $417\div5$ using partial quotients.  Their work is shown below.  Aria's work    $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {5}&\overline{|471}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{400}&\purpleD{80}\\ &71\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{60}&\purpleD{12}\\ &11\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{10}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{2}}\\ &\goldE{1}&\greenE{94}&\goldE{\text{r } 1} \end{array}$  Brynn's work  $\begin{array}{rr|rl} {5}&\overline{|471}\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\purpleD{20}\\ &371\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\purpleD{20}\\ &271\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\purpleD{20}\\ &171\\&\mathllap{-}\underline{100}&\purpleD{20}\\ &71\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{50}&\purpleD{10}\\ &21\\ &\mathllap{-}\underline{20}&\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}\\ &\goldE{1}&\greenE{94}&\goldE{\text{r } 1} \end{array}$  **Whose work is correct?**

Aria and Brynn try to divide $417\div5$ using partial quotients.  Their work is shown below.  |Aria's work  |||| Brynn's work||| -:|-:|-:|-:|-:|-:| -: ${5}$|$\overline{)471}$|||${5}$ | $\overline{)471}$ ||| |$\mathllap{-}\underline{400}$| $\purpleD{80}$| | |$\mathllap{-}\underline{100}$ | $\purpleD{20}$ || |$71$||| | $371$ ||| |$\mathllap{-}\underline{60}$|$\purpleD{12}$|| | $\mathllap{-}\underline{100}$ | $\purpleD{20}$ || |$11$||| | $271$ ||| |$\mathllap{-}\underline{10}$|$\underline{{}+\purpleD{2}}$|| | $\mathllap{-}\underline{100}$ | $\purpleD{20}$ || |$\goldE{1}$|$\greenE{94}$|$\goldE{\text{r } 1}$| |  $171$ ||| |||| | $\mathllap{-}\underline{100}$ | $\purpleD{20}$ || |||||$71$ ||| |||| | $\mathllap{-}\underline{50}$ | $\purpleD{10}$ || |||| | $21$ ||| |||| | $\mathllap{-}\underline{20}$ | $\underline{{}+\purpleD{4}}$ || |||| | $\goldE{1}$ | $\greenE{94}$ | $\goldE{\text{r } 1}$|  **Whose work is correct?**
